docs.lead_paragraph: Annie Oakley did most of her dead-eye shooting in the healthy outdoors. But teen-agers and others who want to emulate her need to be concerned about the hazards of lead exposure at indoor firing ranges. In the Sept. 9 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Michael Shannon, director of the Pediatric Environmental Health Center at Children's Hospital in Boston, reported the cases of four girls, ages 14 to 16, who had significant lead poisoning. The condition can damage the kidneys, bone marrow and nervous system and can harm a fetus during pregnancy.

headline.main: Indoor Shooters, Look Out for the Lead

docs.abstract: Lead poisoning emerges as hazard for young people at indoor firing ranges (S)
docs.snippet: Annie Oakley did most of her dead-eye shooting in the healthy outdoors. But teen-agers and others who want to emulate her need to be concerned about the hazards of lead exposure at indoor firing ranges.    In the Sept. 9 issue of The New England...

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional opponents of abortion rights have come up with yet another scheme to advance their agenda. Called the ''Unborn Victims of Violence Act,'' and scheduled for action today by the House Judiciary Committee, the measure aims to chip away at women's reproductive freedom by granting new legal status to ''unborn children'' -- under the deceptively benign guise of fighting crime. The bill would add to the Federal criminal code a separate new offense to punish individuals who injure or cause the death of a ''child'' who is ''in utero'' -- regardless of the stage of gestation or whether the perpetrator knew of the pregnancy. Under the measure, a prosecutor could choose to pursue a person for harming a fetus independent of whether he prosecuted that same person for harming the mother.

headline.main: Congressional Moves on Violence; On a Dangerous Path to Fetal Rights

docs.abstract: Editorial scores 'yet another scheme' concocted by Congressional opponents of abortion to advance their agenda; notes measure, called Unborn Victims of Violence Act, aims to chip away at women's reproductive freedom by granting new legal status to 'unborn children'

docs.lead_paragraph: After blows were traded throughout the Women's World Championship of the International Chess Federation last month, Jun Xie of China recovered her title by defeating Alisa Galliamova of Russia by 8 1/2 to 6 1/2. The first half of the 16-game match was held in Kazan, Russia, and the second in Shengyang, China. But the matter does not end there. The previous champion, Susan Polgar of Queens, plans to bring legal action against FIDE (the federation's French acronym) for stripping her of her championship and conferring it on Xie. That action was taken after Polgar objected that the prize was too small, that the match had been scheduled too close to her pregnancy and that the site chosen had been Xie's home country.

headline.main: Chinese Grandmaster Wins World Women's Title Again
